projects.heading: Designing graphs for smal screens
projects.subheading: Optimizing Data Visualization for an Electrical Consumption App
projects.introduction: When designing a mobile-friendly energy consumption graph, several key decisions shaped the final outcome:

sections.title: Overview
sections.sectionOne: One of the key pages in an electrical consumption app is where users can monitor their energy usage and costs. While users want insights into their consumption habits across different time periods—ranging from hourly to yearly—electricity companies also aim to help them recognize patterns and adjust their behaviors. This presents a design challenge: how can we create a clear, accessible, and engaging graph that serves both perspectives while remaining easy to use on small screens?

sections.title: 1. Choosing the Right Graph Type
sections.sectionOne: After exploring several options, we settled on a step graph as the most suitable choice. It blends the advantages of line and bar graphs, providing clarity and a more interactive experience without misrepresenting the data.
steps: A line graph suggests continuous data, which doesn’t accurately represent hourly electricity readings where each hour should be treated as a discrete point on the x-axis. However, one advantage of line graphs is that they feel more interactive, inviting users to naturally drag along the curve with their fingers, especially on mobile.

A bar graph visualizes discrete data more correctly, clearly separating each hourly value. On the downside, bars tend to feel more static and can make touch interactions less smooth, especially on smaller screens, where hovering or selecting with precision becomes harder.

By combining the advantages of both, a step graph became the optimal choice. It offers the structural clarity of bars while maintaining the inviting, interactive feel of a line graph. This makes it easy for users to recognize consumption patterns and navigate the data seamlessly on mobile devices.

sections.title: 2. Improving Data Readability on Mobile
sections.sectionOne: Traditional tooltips are commonly used in graphs to display data when hovering, but this pattern does not translate well to mobile apps. On touchscreens, tooltips often end up hidden behind the user’s finger, making them difficult to read. To avoid covering too much of the graph, tooltip text also tends to be small, which further reduces legibility. To solve this, we implemented large, fixed-position data values that remain visible without requiring interaction, ensuring that key information is easy to read — even when navigating with thumbs.

sections.title: 3.  Comparing Different Data Types Without Overload
sections.sectionOne: Users needed to compare both electricity consumption (kWh) and cost per kWh within the same graph. However, multi-variable graphs risk becoming overwhelming. To balance clarity and functionality:
steps: We introduced dual Y-axes with matching visual styles.
Users can choose to toggle comparison data, keeping the default view simple for less advanced users while still enabling deeper insights for those who want them.

sections.title: 4. Enhancing Readability Through Visual Design
sections.sectionOne: To clearly separate datasets:
steps: The main consumption line features a subtle gradient to give it depth without distraction.
Comparison lines use a white border to remain distinct even when colors overlap, without introducing additional gradients or noise.
Color choices were made with accessibility in mind, ensuring that all users — including those with color vision deficiencies — can clearly interpret the data.
Additionally, to ensure accessibility for users with color vision deficiencies, we introduced small graphical markers (circles and squares) on both the graph lines and the corresponding data labels.

sections.title: 5. The date picker for the graph
sections.sectionOne: We also designed a date picker tailored for mobile use, enabling users to easily switch between day, week, month, and year views. It adapts seamlessly to small screens and allows users to explore historical data without friction.

projects.subheading: A Project for learning more about react (2025)
projects.introduction: This webpage is a space where you can get a quick and honest impression of who I am and the work I do. My focus has been on creating a simple and intuitive design without relying on unnecessary animations or flashy distractions. Instead, I’ve built this portfolio to reflect my passion for simplicity, clarity, and functionality.

sections.title: Overview
sections.sectionOne: This webpage is a space where you can get a quick and honest impression of who I am and the work I do. I’ve focused on keeping the design simple and intuitive, avoiding excessive CSS animations —but I couldn't resist adding a playful SVG animation of a logo.

sections.title: Design Process
sections.sectionOne: I have designed this page naturally, drawing inspiration from others and selecting elements that align with my three guiding principles: simplicity, clarity, and efficiency.
steps: Efficiency: While I would love for my readers to learn everything about me, I respect their valuable time and aim to deliver key insights quickly.
Clarity: I want visitors to get a quick glimpse of my work fast enough to capture interest but slow enough to intrigue leaving them wanting to know more.
Simplicity: To be kind to the developer, which happens to be me

sections.title: Colors and Theme Adaptation
sections.sectionOne: The color palette of this portfolio adapts automatically to the visitor’s system theme, creating a smoother and more comfortable experience whether in light or dark mode. This avoids the jarring effect of suddenly landing on a bright page when browsing in dark mode, or a dark page when in light mode. In light mode, the design features a warm beige background and deep green text, chosen for their softness and readability. These same colors are also used in my CV to maintain a consistent and calming visual identity across materials. The dark mode version offers high contrast while remaining easy on the eyes, staying true to my design principles of clarity, simplicity, and efficiency.

sections.title: Creating the webb page, using React
sections.sectionOne: Every part of this portfolio is built using React and Next.js. Building this portfolio has been a learning journey, where I’ve honed my skills in React while keeping the design and functionality aligned with my principles of simplicity, clarity, and efficiency.

projects.heading: Interactive Visualization of Climate Change in the OpenSpace Project
projects.subheading: Master’s Thesis, Linköping University at New York University (2022)
projects.introduction: Designing an interactive storytelling experience about Antarctic ice melt

sections.title: Overview
sections.sectionOne: This project was part of my master’s thesis in media technology at Linköping University, in collaboration with the OpenSpace project, NASA, and the American Museum of Natural History. My goal was to design an interactive visualization of climate change data, focused on Antarctic glaciers, for a general audience.
sections.sectionTwo: The challenge was to take complex satellite datasets and make them understandable, engaging, and explorable through visual storytelling in OpenSpace, a scientific visualization platform used in museums and planetariums.

sections.title: My Role
sections.sectionOne: I was responsible for the full UX and data visualization process.
steps: Researched and storyboarded the climate story with input from experts
Designed and implemented the user interface in React
Developed two navigation modes: a structured narrative and an open-world exploration
Converted scientific datasets from raw formats to visual layers (NetCDF to GeoTIFF to VRT)
Conducted user testing and iterated based on feedback

sections.title: Problem
sections.sectionOne: Climate change data is typically created for researchers. Visualizations are dense, interfaces are complex, and non-expert users often struggle to understand the impact of these changes.
sections.sectionTwo: The question I focused on was: How might we design a visual and interactive experience that allows the general public to explore glacier melting in Antarctica without prior scientific knowledge?

sections.title: Design Process
sections.sectionOne: The design process included four key phases from research to implementation and testing.

subsections.title: 1. Understanding the data and story
subsections.sectionOne: I began by taking an online course on climate science and meeting regularly with a climate physicist at the American Museum of Natural History. Together we identified the Thwaites Glacier (also known as the Doomsday Glacier) as the focal point of the story. I selected satellite datasets such as GRACE (gravity-based ice mass loss) and ECCO (ocean currents) and converted them using Python, GDAL and QGIS into formats that could be displayed on a virtual 3D globe in OpenSpace.

subsections.title: 2. Storyboarding and UX design
subsections.sectionOne: I explored different forms of interactive storytelling and decided to implement two modes:
subSteps: A decision-based narrative, where users could follow a guided story about glacier melting and sea-level rise
An open-world mode, where users could freely explore datasets, switch layers, and zoom in on different parts of Earth
subsections.sectionTwo: Using Figma, I sketched layouts for both story modes, tested UI component placement, and iterated on navigation flows. I focused on keeping Earth in view at all times, with side panels for text, legends, and time controls.

subsections.title: 3. Interface implementation in React
subsections.sectionOne: I developed the interface using React, integrating it with OpenSpace’s OpenGL backend through a custom API. The interface included:
subSteps: A timeline controller to step through time-based datasets
Next and previous buttons for the narrative mode
A story selector and category menu for the open-world mode
Dynamic color legends and info panels that updated per dataset
subsections.sectionTwo: Each component was connected to a JSON-based story API that made it easy to update or extend content.

subsections.title: 4. User testing and iteration
subsections.sectionOne: I conducted think-aloud user testing with seven participants, including climate scientists, OpenSpace developers, and lay users. The sessions revealed several key usability issues:
subSteps: Users misunderstood color mappings (e.g., thought red-blue meant temperature, not ice mass)
Spinning Earth made it hard to focus on reading content
Text lengths needed balancing between too much detail and too little guidance
subsections.sectionTwo: I adjusted the interface accordingly: slowed down animations, clarified legends, refined color schemes, and reorganized information for better accessibility.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.sectionOne: The final interface was successfully integrated into OpenSpace and tested with users of varying backgrounds. It allowed non-experts to explore scientific climate data and learn through interaction.
steps: Follow a narrative about glacier melt and sea-level rise
Explore real climate datasets with minimal friction
Gain a spatial understanding of global currents and local effects
sections.sectionTwo: The storytelling format helped users emotionally connect to abstract scientific data, while the visual tools supported intuitive learning

sections.title: What I Learned
sections.sectionOne: Designing for scientific communication requires careful balance between accuracy and accessibility. I learned how to translate abstract climate data into an intuitive experience, and how to use storytelling as a tool for engagement and education. I also deepened my skills in cross-functional collaboration, working closely with researchers, developers, and museum professionals.
